posts.title: Very Short Introduction Discussions at SNFL: Postcolonialism and Home
posts.text: Last month, Stavros Niarchos Foundation Library hosted the fifth in a monthly series of Very Short Introduction Discussions. February's topic was “Postcolonialism.” If you couldn’t make it to the live discussion, here are some questions to consider while reading.

posts.title: Very Short Introduction Discussions at SNFL: "City Planning" and "Postcolonialism"

posts.title: Very Short Introduction Discussions at SNFL: November's "Knowledge"
posts.text: On November 23, Stavros Niarchos Foundation Library hosted the third in a monthly series of Very Short Introduction Discussions. November’s topic was “Knowledge.” If you couldn’t make it to the live discussion, here are some questions to consider while reading.

posts.title: Very Short Introduction Discussions at SNFL: September's "Work"
posts.text: On September 30, Stavros Niarchos Foundation Library hosted the first in a monthly series of Very Short Introduction Discussions. September’s topic was “Work.” If you couldn’t make it to the live discussion, here are some questions to consider while reading.

posts.title: "Visit" Your Favorite NYC Eateries Via E-Cookbooks
posts.text: Salivate over the photos and get inspired to try making one of their recipes at home.

posts.title: TASC Resources: Find Free Classes and Test Prep for the High School Equivalency Exam (Formerly GED)
posts.text: There are many organizations across New York State that provide assistance with test preparation. On this page are websites with information about this important test and free classes that can help you prepare for it.

posts.title: Patron Picks: The World of Work at Open Book Hour
posts.text: Workplace drama is the focus of this month's patron book recommendations from the May Open Book Hour at the Mid-Manhattan Library.

posts.title: Patron Picks: Migrations and Peregrinations at Open Book Hour
posts.text: Take a look at this month's patron book recommendations featuring immigrants, explorers, and other wanderers in literature.

posts.title: Patron Picks: Revolutionary Women at Open Book Hour
posts.text: Take a look at patrons' book recommendations on incredible women in literature and real life.

posts.title: Patron Picks: Fantastic Realms at Open Book Hour
posts.text: Take a look at patrons' book recommendations that go deep into mythical worlds, from Atlantis to Xanadu.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2018: Books and Music That Jam Together
posts.text: Settle into summer with a great book and the song or album that fits perfectly, in this extensive series of paired recommendations from our NYPL staff.

posts.title: Recommendations on Grief and Loss: Patron and Staff Picks from Open Book Hour
posts.text: What books have you read to help you through a difficult time in your life? Memoir, fiction, poetry, psychology? Find recommendations here.

posts.title: Community Conversations Recap: Literary Life in New York, Then & Now at Mid-Manhattan Library
posts.text: On January 31, Mid-Manhattan Library at 42nd Street hosted its second Community Conversation. Here is an overview of the talk from our guest lecturer, Kevin C. Fitzpatrick. We invite you to join our continuing conversation on the changing media environment ("From Telegrams to Tweets") on February 21.

posts.title: February Reel to Read: Free Saturday Movies at Mid-Manhattan Library at 42nd Street
posts.text: The page meets the screen with Reel to Read, a curated series of independent and classic cinema. These free screenings, hand-picked by local authors and film experts, include a Recommended Reads list inspired by the movies.

posts.title: December Reel to Read: Free Saturday Movies at Mid-Manhattan Library at 42nd Street
posts.text: The page meets the screen at REEL TO READ, a curated series of independent and classic cinema. These free screenings, hand-picked by local authors and film experts, include a Recommended Reads list based on the movie.

posts.title: #NPS100: Celebrating the National Park Service Centennial
posts.text: The library is full of resources for you to plan your visit to or learn about the history of the National Parks.

posts.title: Election 2016: Register, Research, and Vote
posts.text: Resources to help you get ready to vote.

posts.title: E-Book Recommendations to Read in SimplyE
posts.text: Now that SimplyE is here, if you have a smart phone there's no excuse not to be reading everywhere you go! If you're not sure what to pick from the 300,000 titles available, let our staff offer some suggestions.

posts.title: Recipes from the Reluctant Camper
posts.text: Summer would not be complete without a night spent with only a thin layer of nylon separating you from the starry sky and the cool night air... am I right?

posts.title: Women’s History in Digital Collections
posts.text: We bring Women’s History Month to a close with this roundup of representations of and works by women in our Digital Collections. Explore and be inspired.

posts.title: A Super Bowl of Snacks: Books for Making Football Food
posts.text: Some people are there for the game, some people for the commercials, but the rest of us are really just there for the food.

posts.title: Coffee Talk
posts.text: Learn all about coffee's history and cultural influence with your library card.

posts.title: How to Draw, Color, Sketch, Doodle and Tangle
posts.text: Coloring books are all the rage… for the kindergarten set and for grown ups too. You could say it's a fad, but there's nothing quite like putting pencil or crayon to paper and seeing pure creativity flow out, no matter your age.

posts.title: The Ticketless Traveler: Food and Cooking Edition
posts.text: Whether your desire is to visit a faraway locale for a taste of the local delicacies, or just to shake up your weeknight cooking with some new, unfamiliar spices, there is so much inspiration to be found at the library.

posts.title: We All Scream for Ice Cream: Books and Resources for Making Your Own
posts.text: The sun is out, the temps are up... it's time for ice cream.

posts.title: Library Guide to Binge-Watching
posts.text: Libraries are known as centers for books and learning, but sometimes you just want to vegetate on the couch for a few hours with some escapist television.

posts.title: Black Life Matters Wikipedia Edit-a-thon: How You Can Help
posts.text: The Schomburg Wikipedia Edit-a-thon will give patrons the tools to edit the popular online encyclopedia, with the goal of making black life more visible within its pages. If you can't attend in person there are still ways that you can participate wherever you are.

posts.title: How to Clean Things
posts.text: How did you learn how to clean? I guess my parents taught me, and after a few years of chores it just became second nature. Don't mix ammonia and bleach. Sort laundry into light and dark colors. Sweep first before mopping. Make the bed!

posts.title: For Graduation Day and After
posts.text: Congratulations, graduate! There is a big, scary, exciting world out there and it's yours to do whatever it is you'll do next!
